dua.arabic: اَلحَمدُ لِلهِ الَّذِي أحيَانَا بَعْدَ مَا أمَاتَنَا وَ إِلَيهِ النُّشُورُ
dua.translation: Praise is to Allāh Who gives us life after He has caused us to die and to Him is the return.
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#6312), see Fatḥ al-Bārī (11/113), and Muslim (#2711, 4/2083).

dua.arabic: لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ وَحْدَهُ لَا شَرِيكَ لَهُ، لَهُ الْمُلْكُ وَلَهُ الحَمدُ، وَهُوَ عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ، سُبْحاَنَ اللهِ، وَالحَمدُ للهِ، وَلَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ وَاللهُ أَكْبَرُ، وَلَا حَوْلَ وَلَا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللهِ الْعَلِيِّ الْعَظِيمِ، رَبِّ اغْفِرْ لِي
dua.translation: There is none worthy of worship but Allāh alone, Who has no partner, His is the dominion and to Him belongs all praise, and He is able to do all things. Glory is to Allāh. Praise is to Allāh. There is none worthy of worship but Allāh. Allāh is the Most Great. There is no might and no power except by Allāh's leave, the Exalted, the Mighty. My Lord, forgive me. (Whoever says this will be forgiven, and if he supplicates to Allāh, his prayer will be answered; if he performs ablution and prays, his prayer will be accepted.)
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#1154), see Fatḥ al-Bārī (3/39). The wording is of Ibn Mājah (#3878), also see Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Mājah (2/335).

dua.arabic: الحَمدُ لِلهِ الَّذِي عَافَانِي فِي جَسَدِي، وَرَدَّ عَلَيَّ رُوحِي، وَأَذِنَ لِي بِذِكْرِهِ
dua.translation: Praise is to Allāh Who gave strength to my body, He returned my soul to me and permitted me to remember Him.
dua.reference: Al-Tirmidhī (#3401, 5/473), also see Ṣaḥīḥ Al-Tirmidhī (3/144).

dua.arabic: يقرأ سورة آل عمران ٣: ١٩٠-٢٠٠
dua.translation: Recite Sūrah Āl ʿImrān (3:190--200).
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#4572), see Fatḥ al-Bārī (8/237) and Muslim (#763, 1/530).

dua.arabic: اَلحَمدُ لِلهِ الَّذِي كَسَانِي هَذَا (الثَّوْبَ) وَرَزَقَنِيهِ مِنْ غَيْرِ حَولٍ مِنِّي وَ لَا قُوَّةٍ
dua.translation: Praise is to Allāh Who has clothed me with this (garment) and provided it for me, though I was powerless myself and incapable.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#4023) and the wording is his, al-Tirmidhī (#2458) and Ibn Mājah (#3285). Also see Irwāʾ al-Ghalīl (7/47).

dua.arabic: اللَّهُمَّ لَكَ الحَمدُ أَنْتَ كَسَوْتَنِيهِ، أَسْأَلُكَ مِنْ خَيْرِهِ وَخَيْرِ مَا صُنِعَ لَهُ، وَأَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ شَرِّهِ وَشِّرِ مَا صُنِعَ لَهُ
dua.translation: O Allāh, for You is all praise, You have clothed me with it (i.e. the garment), I ask You for the good of it and the good for which it was made, and I seek refuge with You from the evil of it and the evil for which it was made.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#4020) and al-Tirmidhī (#1767) and al-Baghawī. The wording is from Abū Dāwud. Also see Mukhtaṣar Shamāʾil al-Tirmidhī by Al-Albānī (p.\ 47).

group.title: Supplication said to someone wearing new clothes

dua.arabic: تُبْلِي وَيُخْلِفُ اللهُ تَعَالَى
dua.translation: May you wear it out and Allāh replace it (with another).
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#4020, 4/41). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ Abī Dāwud (2/760).

dua.arabic: إِلبَسْ جَدِيداً، وَعِشْ حَمِيداً، وَمُتْ شَهِيداً
dua.translation: Wear anew, live commendably and die a martyr.
dua.reference: Ibn Mājah (#3558, 2/1178) and al-Baghawī (12/41). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Mājah (2/275).

dua.arabic: بِسْمِ اللهِ
dua.translation: In the name of Allah.
dua.reference: Al-Tirmidhī (#606, 2/505) and Sahīh al-Jāmiʿ (#3210, 3/203). Also see Irwāʾ al-Ghalīl (#50).

dua.arabic: (بِسْمِ اللهِ) اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي أَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنَ الْخُبْثِ وَالْخَبَائِثِ
dua.translation: (In the name of Allāh). O Allāh, I take refuge with you from all evil and evil-doers.
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#142, 1/45) and Muslim (#375, 1/283). The narration with the extension "In the name of Allāh" has been collected by Saʿīd bin Manṣūr, see Fatḥ al-Bārī (1/244).

dua.arabic: غُفْرَانَكَ
dua.translation: I ask You (Allāh) for forgiveness.
dua.reference: Al-Tirmidhī (#7), Abū Dāwud (#30), Ibn Mājah (#300), and al-Nasāʾī in ʿAmal al-Yawm wa al-Laylah (#79). Also see the takhrīj of Zād al-Maʿād (2/386).

dua.arabic: بِسْمِ اللهِ
dua.translation: In the name of Allāh.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#101), Ibn Mājah (#399) and Aḥmad (2/418). Also see Irwāʾ al-Ghalīl (1/122).

dua.arabic: أَشْهَدُ أَنْ لَّا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ وَحْدَهُ لاَ شَرِيكَ لَهُ، وَأَشْهَدُ أَنَّ مُحَمَّداً عَبْدُهُ وَرَسُولُهُ
dua.translation: I bear witness that none has the right to be worshipped except Allāh, Alone, without partner, and I bear witness that Muḥammad is His slave and Messenger.

dua.arabic: اللَّهُمَّ اجْعَلْنِي مِنَ التَّوَّابِينَ، وَاجْعَلْنِي مِنَ الْمُتَطَهِّرِينَ
dua.translation: O Allāh, make me of those who return to You often in repentance and make me of those who remain clean and pure.
dua.reference: Al-Tirmidhī (#55, 1/78). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ al-Tirmidhī (1/18).

dua.arabic: سُبْحَانَكَ اللَّهُمَّ وَبِحَمْدِكَ، أَشْهَدُ أَنْ لَّا إِلٰهَ إِلَّا أَنْتَ، أَسْتَغْفِرُكَ وَأَتُوبُ إِلَيكَ
dua.translation: How perfect You are O Allāh, and I praise You, I bear witness that none has the right to be worshipped except You, I seek Your forgiveness and turn in repentance to You.
dua.reference: Al-Nasāʾī in ʿAmal al-Yawm wa al-Laylah (#81, p.\ 173). Also see Irwāʾ al-Ghalīl (3/94).

dua.arabic: بِسْمِ اللهِ، تَوَكَّلْتُ عَلَى اللهِ، وَلاَحَوْلَ وَلَا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللهِ
dua.translation: In the name of Allāh, I place my trust in Allāh, and there is no might nor power except with Allāh.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#5094, 4/325) and al-Tirmidhī (#3427, 5/490). See Ṣaḥīḥ al-Tirmidhī (3/151).

dua.arabic: اللَّهُمَّ إِنَّي أَعْوْذُ بِكَ أَنْ أَضِلَّ، أَوْ أُضِلَّ، أَوْ أَزِلَّ، أُوْ أُزَلَّ أَوْ أَظْلِمَ، أَوْ أُظْلَمَ، أَوْ أَجْهَلَ، أَوْ يُجْهَلَ عَلَيَّ
dua.translation: O Allāh, I take refuge with You lest I should stray or be led astray, or slip or be tripped, or oppress or be oppressed, or behave foolishly or be treated foolishly.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#5094), al-Tirmidhī (#3427), al-Nasāʾī (8/268) and Ibn Mājah (#3884). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ al-Tirmidhī (3/152) and Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Mājah (2/336).

dua.arabic: بِسْمِ اللَّهِ وَلَجْنَا، وَبِسْمِ اللَّهِ خَرَجْنَا، وَعَلَى اللهِ رَبَّنَا تَوَكَّلْنَا
dua.translation: In the name of Allāh we enter and in the name of Allāh we leave, and upon our Lord we place our trust.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#5096, 4/325) and Muslim (#2018). Shaykh ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz bin Bāz graded the chain of the former ḥasan in Tuḥfah al-Akhyār (p.\ 28).

group.title: Supplication when going to the Masjid

dua.arabic: اللَّهُمَّ اجْعَلْ فِي قَلْبِي نُوْراً، وَفِي لِسَانِي نُوْراً، وَ فِي سَمْعِي نُوْراً، وَ فِي بَصَري نُوْراً، وَ مِنْ فَوقِي نُوْراً، وَمِنْ تحْتِي نُوْراً، وَعَنْ يَمِيْنِي نُوْراً، وَ عَنْ شِمَالِي نُوْراً، وَ مِنْ أَمَامِي نُوْراً، وَ مِنْ خَلْفِي نُوراً، واجْعَلْ فِي نَفْسِي نُوراً، وَ أعْظِمْ لي نُوراً، وَ عَظِّمْ لي نُوراً، وَاجْعَلْ لي نُوراً، وَاجْعَلْنِي نُوراً، اللهم أَعْطِنِي نُوراً، وَاجْعَلْ في عَصَبِي نُوراً، وَ في لَحْمِي نُوراً، وَ في دَمِي نُوراً، وَ في شَعْرِي نُوراً، وَ في بَشَرِي نُوراً[1]. [اللهم اجْعَلْ لي نُوراً في قَبْرِي...وَ نُوراً في عِظَامِي][2] [وَ زِدْنِي نُوراً، وَ زِدْنِي نُوراً، وَ زِدْنِي نُوراً][1] [وَهَبْ لِي نُوراً عَلَى نُورٍ][2].
dua.translation: O Allāh, place within my heart light, and upon my tongue light, and within my ears light, and within my eyes light, and place behind me light and in front of me light and above me light and beneath me light. O Allāh, bestow upon me light.

dua.arabic: (يَبْدَأُ بِرِجْلِهِ اليُمْنَى)[1]، ويقول: (أَعُوْذُ بِاللَّهِ الْعَظِيمِ، وَبِوَجْهِهِ الْكَرِيمِ، وَسُلْطَانِهِ الْقَدِيمِ، مِنَ الشَّيْطَانِ الرَّجِيمِ)[2]، (بِسْمِ اللَّهِ, وَالصَّلاةُ)[3]. [وَالسَّلامُ عَلَى رَسُوْلِ اللَّهِ][4]، (اللَّهُمَّ افْتَحْ لِي أَبْوَابَ رَحْمَتِكَ)[5].
dua.translation: (Enter with your right foot[1] and say:) “I take refuge with Allāh, the Supreme and with His Noble Face, and His eternal authority from the accursed devil.[2] In the name of Allāh, and prayers[3] and peace be upon the Messenger of Allāh.[4] O Allāh, open the gates of Your mercy for me.”[5]
dua.reference:
[1] Al-Ḥākim (1/218) and he authenticated it with the conditions of Muslim and al-Dhahabī agreed with him, al-Bayhaqī (2/442), and al-Albānī declared it ḥasan in Silsilah al-Ahādīth al-Ṣaḥīḥah (#2478, 5/624). [2] Abū Dāwud (#466). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ al-Jāmiʿ (#4591). [3] Al-Nisā'i (#88) and Al-Albānī declared it ḥasan. [4] Abū Dāwud (#465, 1/126). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ al-Jāmiʿ (#514, 1/528). [5] Muslim (#713, 1/494), and Ibn Mājah (#771) from the ḥadīth of Fāṭimah with the wording (
اللهم اغفرلي ذنوبي، وافتح لي أبواب رحمتك) and al-Albānī declared it ṣaḥīḥ due to its shawāhid; see Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Mājah (1/128-129).
